The Sage first diverges and then harmonizes; the common crowd first harmonizes and then diverges. Therefore, the gates of calamity and blessing, the reversal of benefit and harm, cannot be overlooked.

Laozi said: **"Those with merit who abandon virtue and righteousness will be met with suspicion; those with guilt who uphold virtue and righteousness will be trusted. Thus, virtue and righteousness are the constant path of proper conduct, the esteemed rank of the world. Though plans and strategies may be sound, if actions stray from virtue and righteousness, their merit will not be fulfilled. Though words may lack precision in policy, if their intent is loyal and their counsel benefits the state, yet their heart is devoted to the ruler and aligned with virtue and righteousness, their life will be preserved. Therefore, it is said: 'Even if one’s words and plans are always wrong, it is better to abandon them and carefully uphold virtue and righteousness.'

Laozi said: 'Teaching originates from the *junzi*; the petty person benefits from its influence. Profit originates from the petty person; the *junzi* enjoys its merit. If the *junzi* and petty person each find their proper place, then governance becomes effortless and the Dao is realized. People who desire much will harm virtue; those who worry much will impair wisdom. Therefore, in governing a state—what brings joy ensures survival, what brings sorrow leads to ruin.

Water flows downward, vast and expansive; the ruler submits to ministers, wise and discerning. If the ruler does not contend with ministers, the Way of governance flows smoothly. Thus, the ruler is the root and foundation, the ministers are branches and leaves. If the root is not flourishing yet the branches are lush, such a thing has never existed.

Laozi said: 'The loving kindness of a benevolent father toward his child is not sought for its return; it cannot be resolved within the heart. The nurturing of a wise sovereign toward the people is not for the sake of scholars; it is the nature of things, inevitable. But if one relies on their strength and exploits their merits, they will inevitably reach ruin, and those who depend on them will find their favor does not extend.

Thus, if one employs what the common people love, they will gain the common people’s strength; if one raises what the common people delight in, they will win the common people’s hearts. Therefore, observe their beginning, and you will know their end.

Laozi said: 'People are bound by virtue; factions are strengthened by cliques. Thus, if the scope of what is granted is broad, the influence of what is enforced will be far-reaching. If virtue is applied thinly, the force of what is restrained will be small.

Laozi said: 'If one gains through unrighteousness and does not distribute it, misfortune will befall them. They cannot benefit others, nor themselves—this can be called a foolish person, no different from the owl that loves its young. Therefore, it is said: *"Clutching and hoarding cannot compare to letting go; probing and scheming cannot endure long."* Virtue and the Dao are intertwined; the Dao and virtue are inseparable. Their transformations are boundless. Within the bright is the dark; within the dark is the bright. All things follow this pattern, beyond measure.

Blessings come with auspicious signs; calamities precede with omens. If one sees auspicious signs yet does not act virtuously, blessings will not arrive. If one sees inauspicious signs yet acts virtuously, calamities will not befall. Benefit and harm share the same threshold; calamity and blessing are neighbors. Only the divine and the Sage can distinguish them. Therefore, it is said: *"Calamity, oh calamity, is the foundation of blessing; blessing, oh blessing, is the seed of calamity—who can know their limits?"*

When people are about to fall ill, they first crave the taste of fish and meat. When a state is about to fall, it first despises the words of loyal ministers. Thus, the dying cannot be healed by a skilled physician, nor can a doomed state be saved by loyal counsel.

Cultivate oneself first, then one can govern the people. Manage one’s household properly, then one can be entrusted with official duties. Therefore, it is said: *"Cultivate oneself, and one’s virtue becomes genuine; cultivate one’s household, and one’s virtue has surplus; cultivate one’s state, and one’s virtue becomes abundant."*

The people’s means of survival are clothing and food. If matters concerning clothing and food are well attended, there will be merit; if neglected, there will be none. Matters without merit cannot endure long.

Thus, if one follows the times yet does not succeed, do not alter the laws. If one conforms to the times yet does not succeed, do not change the principles. When the times shift again, this is called the rhythm of the Dao.

The Emperor enriches his people; the King enriches his land. A ruler in peril enriches his officials; a well-governed state seems lacking in wealth. A ruined state has empty granaries. Therefore, it is said: *"When the ruler has no affairs, the people naturally prosper; when the ruler does nothing, the people naturally transform."*

Raising an army of ten thousand men, daily expenditures of a thousand gold—*"After the campaign’s return, there will surely be a year of misfortune."* Thus, it is said: *"Warfare is an inauspicious instrument; it is not the treasure of the *junzi*."* *"Conciliating great grudges will surely leave lingering grudges,"*—how can this be considered good?

In ancient times, those who were close were not treated differently by speech; those who were distant were not treated differently by speech. The near were made to delight, the distant were made to come.

If one shares the people’s desires, harmony will follow; if one shares the people’s safeguards, stability will follow; if one shares the people’s thoughts, wisdom will follow. Those who gain the people’s strength will be rich; those who gain the people’s praise will be honored. Actions invite enemies; words bring calamity. Do not speak before others; speak after others have spoken.

Whispered words may spread a thousand miles. The speaker invites calamity; the tongue is a mechanism. If words are spoken inappropriately, not even four horses can outrun their consequences.

Once, Zhonghuangzi said: *"Heaven has five directions, Earth has five phases, sound has five tones, things have five flavors, colors have five hues, and people have five stations. Thus, between Heaven and Earth, there are twenty-five kinds of people.

The highest five are the divine person, the true person, the Dao person, the perfect person, and the Sage. The next five are the virtuous person, the worthy person, the wise person, the good person, and the eloquent person. The middle five are the upright person, the loyal person, the trustworthy person, the righteous person, and the ceremonious person. The next five are the scholar, the artisan, the hunter, the farmer, and the merchant. The lowest five are the common person, the slave, the foolish person, the brute, and the petty person. The highest five and the lowest five differ as much as people differ from cattle and horses.

The Sage observes with the eyes, listens with the ears, speaks with the mouth, and acts with the feet.

The True person does not observe yet is clear, does not listen yet is discerning, does not act yet is followed, does not speak yet is upright."*

What pleases the eyes, what pleases the heart—this is what the foolish Dao profits from, yet what the one who knows the Dao avoids."**

chunks.original_text: 故圣人所以动天下者，真人未尝过焉，贤人所以矫世俗者，圣人未尝观焉。 所谓道者，无前无后，无左无右，万物玄同，无是无非。 卷第八 自然 老子曰：清虚者，天之明也，无为者，治之常也，去恩惠，舍圣智，外贤能，废仁义，灭事故，弃佞辩，禁奸伪，则贤不肖者齐于道矣。 静则同，虚则通，至德无为，万物皆容，虚静之道，天长地久，神微周盈，于物无宰。 十二月运行，周而复始，金木水火土，其势相害，其道相待。 故至寒伤物，无寒不可，至暑伤物，无暑不可，故可与不可皆可，是以大道无所不可，可在其理，见可不趋，见不可不去，可与不可，相为左右，相为表里。 凡事之要，必从一始，时为之纪，自古及今，未尝变易，谓之天理。 上执大明，下用其光，道生万物，理于阴阳，化为四时，分为五行，各得其所，与时往来，法度有常，下及无能，上道不倾，群臣一意，天地之道无为而备，无求而得，「是以知其无为而有益也。 」 老子曰：朴，至大者无形状，道，至大者无度量，故天员不中规，地方不中矩。 往古来今谓之宙，四方上下谓之宇，道在中而莫知其所，故见不远者，不可与言大，知不博者，不可与论至。 夫道与物通者，无以相非，故三皇五帝法籍殊方，其得民心一也。 若夫规矩勾绳，巧之具也，而非所以巧也，故无弦虽师文不能成其曲，徒弦则不能独悲，故弦，悲之具也，非所以为悲也。 至于神和，游于心手之间，放意写神，论爱而形于弦者，父不能以教子，子亦不能受之于父，此不传之道也。 故肃者形之君也，而寂寞者音之主也。 老子曰：天地之道，以德为主，道为之命，物以自正。 至微甚内，不以事贵，故不待功而立，不以位为尊，不待名而显，不须礼而庄，不用兵而强。 故道立而不教，明照而不察，道立而不教者，不夺人能也，明照而不察者，不害其事也。 夫教道者，逆于德，害于物，故阴阳四时，金木水火土，同道而异理，万物同情而异形。 智者不相教，能者不相受，故圣人立法，以导民之心，各使自然，故生者无德，死者无怨。 天地不仁，以万物为刍狗，圣人不仁，以百姓为刍狗。 夫慈爱仁义者，近狭之道也，狭者入大而迷，近者行远而惑，圣人之道，入大不迷，行远不惑，常虚自守，可以为极，是谓天德。 老子曰：圣人天覆地载，日月照临，阴阳和，四时化，怀万物而不同，无故无新，无疏无亲，故能法天者，天不一时，地不一材，人不一事，故绪业多端，趋行多方。 故用兵者，或轻或重，或贪或廉，四者相反，不可一也，轻者欲发，重者欲止，贪者欲取，廉者不利非其有也。 故勇者可令进斗，不可令持坚，重者可令固守，不可令凌敌，贪者可令攻取，不可令分财，廉者可令守分，不可令进取，信者可令持约，不可令应变，五者，圣人兼用而材使之。 夫天地不怀一物，阴阳不产一类，故海不让水潦以成其大，山林不让枉桡以成其崇，圣不辞其负薪之言以广其名。 夫守一隅而遗万方，取一物而弃其余，则所得者寡，而所治者浅矣。 老子曰：天之所覆，地之所载，日月之所照，形殊性异，各有所安，乐所以为乐者，乃所以为悲也，安所以为安者，乃所以为危也。

Thus, the Sage moves the world through his virtue, yet the True Person has never surpassed him. The worthy person corrects the common customs, yet the Sage has never observed them.

The so-called **Dao/Way** is without before or after, without left or right. All things merge in mysterious unity, neither affirming nor denying.

**Chapter Eight: Naturalness**
Laozi says: **"Qīngxū** [purity and emptiness] is the clarity of Heaven, **wúwéi** [non-action] is the constant of governance. To abandon favor and wisdom, discard the virtues of the worthy and the cunning of the Sage, forsake skillful talents, reject benevolence and righteousness, extinguish old customs, abandon artful persuasion, and suppress deceit—then the worthy and the unworthy alike will align with the Dao.

**Stillness brings unity; emptiness brings harmony.** The ultimate **virtue/power** is **non-action**, yet all things find their place. The Dao of **emptiness and stillness** endures as vast as Heaven and enduring as Earth, its subtlety infinite and overflowing, yet it does not dominate any thing.

The twelve months move in cycles, returning without end. **Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth**—their forces oppose yet their **Dao/Way** complements each other. So extreme cold harms things, yet without cold, it would be impossible. Extreme heat harms things, yet without heat, it would be impossible. Thus, what is possible and what is impossible both arise from possibility, hence the great **Dao/Way** has no absolute impossibility. It lies in its **lǐ** [principle/reason], seeing what is possible yet not rushing toward it, seeing what is impossible yet not avoiding it. What is possible and what is impossible are like the left and right, the exterior and interior of each other.

The essence of all things must begin with **one**; time serves as its measure. From ancient times to the present, it has never altered or changed—this is called **Heavenly lǐ**. Above, it holds the great clarity; below, it utilizes its radiance. The **Dao/Way** gives birth to all things, its **lǐ** rests in **Yīnyáng** [yin-yang], its transformation becomes the four seasons, its division the five phases. Each finds its place, moving with the times, yet its laws remain constant. Even the lowliest of beings conforms, while the **Dao/Way** itself remains uninclined. When all ministers are of one mind, the **Dao/Way** of Heaven and Earth is **non-action** yet complete, **non-seeking** yet fulfilled. *"Hence one knows its benefit lies in non-action."*

Laozi says: **"Pǔ** [uncarved simplicity], the greatest of all, has no form; the **Dao/Way**, the greatest of all, has no measure. Thus, Heaven’s compass is not bound by the circle, Earth’s square is not confined by the rule. The past and present are called **zhòu** [duration], the four directions and above and below are called **yǔ** [space]. The **Dao/Way** dwells in the midst yet is unknown in its location. Thus, those who see not far cannot be spoken to of the great, those who know not broadly cannot be instructed on the ultimate.

The **Dao/Way** that communicates with all things cannot be contradicted. Hence the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors, though their laws and systems varied by region, all won the hearts of the people in the same way.

If one speaks of **rulers and measures, hooks and cords**—these are tools of craft, yet not the essence of craft. Thus, even with a master, a stringless instrument cannot produce its melody, and a lone string cannot weep alone. The string is but the tool for weeping, not the weeping itself.

When **shén** [spirit] and **hé** [harmony] are achieved, they play between the heart and hands. To let the mind wander freely and express the **spirit** through the strings, to discuss love yet reveal it in the music—this is a **Dao/Way** that cannot be taught. A father cannot teach it to his son, nor can a son receive it from his father. This is the **Dao/Way** that does not transmit.

Thus, **sù** [solemnity] is the sovereign of form, while **jìmiào** [silence and solitude] is the master of sound.

Laozi says: The **Dao/Way** of Heaven and Earth is rooted in **virtue/power**, the **Dao/Way** itself is its command, and all things regulate themselves.

The most subtle and profound does not serve the noble, hence it does not await merit to establish itself, nor does it rely on rank for its honor, nor does it seek reputation for its brilliance, nor does it need ceremony for its dignity, nor does it employ force for its strength. Thus, the **Dao/Way** stands yet does not instruct, its clarity shines yet does not scrutinize. The **Dao/Way** stands yet does not instruct, for it does not usurp others’ abilities; its clarity shines yet does not scrutinize, for it does not harm their undertakings.

To teach the **Dao/Way** is to go against **virtue/power**, to harm all things. Hence **Yīnyáng** and the four seasons, **Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth**—though they share the same **Dao/Way**, their **lǐ** differs. All things share the same **qíng** [emotion], yet their forms vary.

The wise do not instruct each other, the skilled do not take from each other. Thus the Sage establishes laws to guide the hearts of the people, letting each follow their nature. Hence the living have no grievance, the dead no resentment.

Heaven and Earth are not benevolent; they treat all things as **chúdài** [sacrificial cattle]. The Sage is not benevolent; he treats the people as **chúdài**. Benevolence, love, and righteousness are narrow **Dao/Way**s. The narrow cannot enter the great without confusion, the near cannot travel far without doubt. The **Dao/Way** of the Sage enters the great without confusion, travels far without doubt. He constantly guards himself in **emptiness**, and thus can attain the utmost—this is called **Heavenly virtue/power**.

Laozi says: The Sage is covered by Heaven, borne by Earth, illuminated by the sun and moon. **Yīnyáng** harmonizes, the four seasons transform, yet he embraces all things without distinction. He neither clings to the old nor pursues the new, neither shuns the distant nor favors the near. Thus, those who can follow Heaven’s **Dao/Way** know that Heaven does not adhere to a single time, Earth does not limit itself to one material, and people do not pursue one path. Hence their undertakings are manifold, their actions diverse.

Thus, those who use arms may be **light or heavy**, **greedy or restrained**—these four are contrary, and cannot be unified. The **light** may be ordered to advance, yet they cannot be commanded to hold firm; the **heavy** may be ordered to defend, yet they cannot be commanded to assail. The **greedy** may be ordered to take, yet they cannot be commanded to distribute wealth; the **restrained** may be ordered to keep their share, yet they cannot be commanded to advance. The **trustworthy** may be ordered to keep their oaths, yet they cannot be commanded to adapt to change. These five, the Sage employs them all yet measures their use.

Heaven and Earth do not cherish any single thing, **Yīnyáng** does not favor any single type. Thus the sea does not refuse the smallest streams to become great, the mountains and forests do not reject the crooked and bent to become lofty. The Sage does not reject the humble words of a woodcutter to broaden his name.

To guard one corner while abandoning the world, to take one thing while discarding the rest—then what is gained is few, and what is governed is shallow.

Laozi says: What Heaven covers and Earth bears, what the sun and moon illuminate—though their forms differ and their natures vary, each finds its own repose. Joy is the means of joy, yet it is also the means of sorrow. Safety is the means of safety, yet it is also the means of danger.

chunks.original_text: 故圣人之牧民也，使各便其性，安其居，处为其所能，周其所适，施其所宜，如此即万物一齐，无由相过。 天下之物，无贵无贱，因其所贵而贵之，物无不贵，因其所贱而贱之，物无不贱，故不尚贤者，言不放鱼于木，不沈鸟于渊。 昔尧之治天下也，舜为司徒，契为司马，禹为司空，后稷为田畴，奚仲为工师，其导民也，水处者渔，林处者采，谷处者牧，陵处者田，地宜事，事宜其械，械宜其材，皋泽织网，陵坡耕田，如是外民得以所有易所无，以所工易所拙。 是以离叛者寡，听从者众，若风之过萧，忽然而感之，各以清浊应，物莫不就其所利，避其所害。 是以邻国相望，鸡狗之音相闻，而足迹不接于诸侯之境，车轨不结于千里之外，皆安其居也。 故乱国若盛，治国若虚，亡国若不足，存国若有余。 虚者，非无人也，各守其职也，盛者，非多人也，皆徼于未也，有余者，非多财也，欲节事寡也，不足者，非无货也，民鲜而费多也，故先王之法，非所作也，所因也，其禁诛，非所为也，所守也，上德之道也。 老子曰：以道治天下，非易人性也，因其所有而循畅之，故因即大，作即小。 古之渎水者，因水之流也，生稼者，因地之宜也，征伐者，因民之欲也，能因则无敌于天下矣。 物必有自然而人事有治也，故先王之制法，因民之性而为之节文，无其性，不可使顺教，无其资，不可使遵道。 人之性有仁义之资，其非圣人为之法度，不可使向方，因其所恶以禁奸，故刑罚不用，威行如神，因其性即天下听从，怫其性即法度张而不用。 道德者，则功名之本也，民之所怀也，怀之则功名立。 古之善为君者法江海，江海无为以成其大，洼下以成其广，故能长久，为天下溪谷，其德乃足，无为能取百川，不求故能得，不行故能至，是以取天下而无事。 不自奉故富，不自见故明，不自矜故长，处不肖之地，故为天下王，不争故莫能与之争，终不为大故能成其大，江海近于道，故能长久，与天地相保。 公正修道，即功成不有，不有即强固，强固而不以暴人，道深即德深，德深即功名遂成，此谓玄德深矣！ 远矣！ 其与物反矣！

The Sage governs the people by allowing each to follow its nature, to dwell in comfort, to engage in what they are capable of, to fulfill their proper roles, and to act according to what is fitting. Thus all things harmonize, and none overstep their bounds.

All things under Heaven have neither nobility nor lowliness—what is valued is valued because of its worth, and all things are thus worthy; what is demeaned is demeaned because of its lack, and all things are thus unworthy. Therefore, the Sage does not exalt the worthy, nor does he cast fish upon trees or drown birds in the deep.

In ancient times, when Emperor Yao ruled the world, Shun was Minister of Instruction, Xiè was Minister of War, Yǔ was Minister of Works, Hòuxī was Overseer of Agriculture, Xī Zhòng was Master of Crafts. In guiding the people, those dwelling by water fished, those dwelling in forests gathered, those dwelling in valleys herded, and those dwelling on hills tilled. The land dictated their labor, their tools suited their tasks, and their tools were crafted from fitting materials. Marshes and wetlands were woven into nets, hillsides were plowed into fields. Thus, the people exchanged what they lacked for what they possessed, and what they were unskilled in for what they excelled at.

Hence, few deserted their homes, and many obeyed. Like wind passing through reeds, it stirred them effortlessly, and each responded according to purity or turbidity. All things naturally sought what benefited them and avoided what harmed them.

Thus neighboring states, though close enough to hear the sounds of roosters and dogs, never set foot upon one another’s borders, nor did their cart tracks meet beyond a thousand *lǐ*. All simply dwelled in peace.

Therefore, chaotic states appear full, yet are empty; well-ordered states appear sparse, yet are abundant. States on the verge of ruin seem lacking, yet are preserved; thriving states seem excessive, yet endure. The "empty" is not without people—each fulfills their role. The "full" is not from excess—all are merely awaiting their turn. The "abundant" is not from wealth—it is from moderating desires and reducing expenditures. The "lacking" is not from scarcity—it is from few people and many costs.

Thus the laws of the ancient kings were not their own creation, but what they followed. Their punishments were not their own invention, but what they upheld. This is the Dao of supreme virtue.

Laozi said: To govern the world with the Way is not to alter human nature, but to follow what already exists and let it flow freely. Thus, to follow is to become great; to force is to become small.

Ancient waterway builders followed the flow of water, farmers followed the suitability of the land, and warriors followed the desires of the people. To follow naturally is to be invincible under Heaven.

All things have their natural order, and human affairs have their proper governance. Therefore, the ancient kings established laws by aligning with human nature and setting appropriate boundaries. Without their inherent nature, people cannot be made to conform to teachings. Without their resources, they cannot be made to follow the Way.

Human nature contains the potential for virtue and righteousness, yet without the Sage’s laws and measures, they cannot be directed aright. By guiding them away from what they dislike, punishments are rendered unnecessary, and authority becomes as potent as the divine. To align with their nature is to have the world obey; to defy it is to see laws enacted yet ignored.

Virtue and the Way are the foundation of merit and renown, what the people cherish. When cherished, merit and renown are established.

The ancient wise rulers modeled themselves after the rivers and seas: the rivers and seas achieve greatness through non-action, broaden themselves through humility, and thus endure. They become the valleys of the world, their virtue sufficient. Through non-action, they receive all rivers; through not seeking, they obtain all; through not striving, they arrive. Thus they take the world without conflict.

By not self-aggrandizing, they grow rich; by not self-displaying, they grow clear; by not self-exalting, they endure. Dwelling in unremarkable places, they become kings of the world. By not contending, none can contend with them. By never striving to be great, they achieve greatness. The rivers and seas are close to the Way, and thus endure, preserving themselves alongside Heaven and Earth.

When public rectitude and the Way are cultivated, merit is achieved without possession. Without possession, strength is unshaken. Unshaken yet not tyrannical over others, deep in the Way, deep in virtue, merit and renown are thus fulfilled. This is called profound virtue! Profound! It transcends all things and returns to their origin.

chunks.original_text: 天下有始，莫知其理，唯圣人能知所以，非雄非雌，非牝非牡，生而不死，天地以成，阴阳以形，万物以生。 故阴与阳，有员有方，有短有长，有存有亡，道为之命，幽沉而光事，于心甚微，于道甚当，死生同理，万物变化，合于一道。 简生忘死，何往不寿，去事与言，慎无为也。 守道周密，于物不宰，至微无形，天地之始，万物同于道而殊形，至微无物，故能周恤，至大无外，故为万物盖，至细无内，故为万物贵。 道之存生，德之安形，至道之度，去好去恶，无有知故，易意和心，无以道迕。 夫天地专而为一，分而为二，交而合之，上下不失，专而为一，分而为五，反而合之，必中规矩。 夫道至亲不可疏，至近不可远，求之近者，往而复反。 老子曰：帝者有名，莫知其情，帝者贵其德，王者尚其义，霸者迫于理。 圣人之道，于物无有，道挟然后任智，德薄然后任形，明浅然后任察。 任智者中心乱，任刑者上下怨，任察者下求善以事上即弊。 是以圣人因天地以变化，其德乃天覆而地载，道之以时，其养乃厚，厚养即治，虽有神圣，人何以易之。 去心智，故省刑罚，反清静，物将自正。 道之为君如尸，俨然玄默，而天下受其福，一人被之不裒，万人被之不褊。 是故重为惠，重为暴，即道迕矣。 为惠者布施也，无功而厚赏，无劳而高爵，即守职懈于官，而游居者亟于进矣。 夫暴者妄诛也，无罪而死亡，行道者而被刑，即修身不劝善，而为邪行者轻犯上矣。 故为惠者即生奸，为暴者即生乱，奸乱之俗，亡国之风也。 故国有诛者而主无怒也，朝有赏者而君无与也，诛者不怨君，罪之当也，赏者不德上，功之致也，民知诛赏之来，皆生于身，故务功修业，不受赐于人，是以朝廷芜而无迹，田野辟而无秽，故太上下知而有之。 王道者，处无为之事，行不言之教，清静而不动，一度而不摇，因循任下，责成不劳，谋无失策，举无过事，言无文章，行无仪表，进退应时，动静循理，美丑不好憎，赏罚不喜怒。 名各自命，类各自以，事由自然，莫出于己，若欲狭之，乃是离之，若欲饰之，乃是贼之。 天气为魂，地气为魄，反之玄妙，各处其宅，守之勿失，上通太一，太一之精，通合于天。 天道嘿嘿，无容无则，大不可极，深不可测，常与人化，智不能得，轮转无端，化逐如神，虚无因循，常后而不先。 其听治也，虚心弱志，清明不暗，是故群臣辐凑并进，无愚智贤不肖，莫不尽其能，君得所以制臣，臣得所以事君，即治国之所以明矣。 老子曰：知而好问者圣，勇而好问者胜，乘众人之智者即无不任也，用众人之力者即无不胜也，用众人之力者，乌获不足恃也，乘众人之势者，天下不足用也。 无权不可为之势，而不循道理之数，虽神圣人不能以成名。 故圣人举事，未尝不因其资而用之也，有一形者处一位，有一能者服一事，力胜其任，即举者不重也，能胜其事，即为者不难也。 圣人兼而用之，故人无弃人物无弃材。 老子曰：所谓无为者，非谓其引之不来，推之不去，迫而不应，感而不动，坚滞而不流，卷握而不散，谓其私志不入公道，嗜欲不挂正术，循理而举事，因资而立功，推自然之势，曲故不得容，事成而身不伐，功立而名不有，若夫水用舟，涉用●，泥用輴，山用樏，夏渎冬陂，因高为山，因下为池，非吾所为也。

The world has a beginning, yet none know its principle, save the sage who alone understands its source.
Neither male nor female, neither yin nor yang,
Life yet never dies—
Heaven and Earth are formed by it,
Yin and Yang take shape through it,
All things arise from it.

Thus yin and yang,
Have roundness and angularity,
Shortness and length,
Preservation and destruction—
The Dao names them all.
Deep and hidden yet luminous in its workings,
In the heart, it is subtle,
In the Way, it is fitting.
Life and death share the same principle,
All things change and merge into One Dao.

To disregard life, to forget death—
Where would one not grow old?
To abandon action and speech—
Be cautious of inaction.

To uphold the Dao with thoroughness,
One does not slaughter things.
In its utmost subtlety, it is formless—
The origin of Heaven and Earth.
All things conform to the Dao yet differ in form—
In its utmost subtlety, it is without substance,
And thus can encompass all with care.
In its utmost greatness, it has no bounds—
It shelters all things beneath.
In its utmost refinement, it is without interior—
It is the treasure of all things.

The Dao sustains life,
Virtue shapes existence—
The measure of the utmost Dao:
Abandoning preference and aversion,
Without knowing yet without fault,
Adjusting intentions to harmonize the heart,
Never opposing the Way.

Now Heaven and Earth,
Concentrated, become One,
Divided, become Two,
Interacting, they unite—
Above and below, they never fail.
Concentrated, they become One,
Divided, they become Five,
Yet when they return, they must align with the square and the compass.

The Dao is most intimate yet cannot be slighted,
Most near yet cannot be distanced—
Seeking it in the near, one goes and returns.

Laozi said:
*The Emperor* has a name, yet none know his nature;
*The Emperor* values virtue,
The king prizes righteousness,
The hegemon is constrained by principle.

The sage’s Way is without partiality—
The Way is first, then wisdom is employed,
Virtue is thin, then form is applied,
Insight is shallow, then discernment is used.
Those who rely on wisdom have troubled hearts,
Those who rely on punishment have resentment above and below,
Those who rely on discernment seek favor from the superior to serve their own ends—
Thus they bring ruin.

Therefore the sage follows the transformations of Heaven and Earth,
And his virtue is like Heaven’s canopy and Earth’s foundation.
The Way is practiced in due measure,
And his nourishment is profound.
Profound nourishment brings order—
Even gods and saints cannot easily surpass it.

Abandoning the heart’s schemes,
Punishments are reduced—
Returning to purity and stillness,
Things will naturally align.

The Dao as ruler is like a corpse—
Solemn and silent,
Yet the world receives its blessings.
One person benefits from it without partiality,
Ten thousand benefit without favoritism.

Thus heavy kindness is as harmful as heavy cruelty—
Both deviate from the Way.
Heavy kindness spreads gifts,
Bestowing rewards without merit,
Granting honors without labor—
Then those who hold office slack in their duties,
While idlers rush forward in ambition.

Heavy cruelty is arbitrary execution,
Death without fault,
Punishment of the righteous—
Then those who cultivate their conduct do not encourage goodness,
While the wicked dare to defy their superiors.

Thus heavy kindness breeds deceit,
Heavy cruelty breeds chaos—
Deceit and chaos are the winds of fallen states.

Therefore when punishments are meted out, the ruler feels no anger,
When rewards are given, the sovereign does not share—
The punished do not blame the ruler,
For the punishment is just.
The rewarded do not credit the sovereign,
For the reward is earned.
The people know that punishments and rewards arise from their own deeds,
Thus they strive in their duties and cultivate their arts—
No gifts are received from others.
Hence the court is uncluttered yet without neglect,
The fields are open yet without filth—
Thus the *Taishang* knows yet does not possess.

The kingly Way is to dwell in the affairs of non-action,
To practice the teaching of non-speech,
To be pure and still, unmoved—
To measure once and never sway.
To follow naturally, to let things unfold,
To complete without labor,
To plan without losing strategy,
To act without error,
To speak without ornaments,
To move without display,
To advance and retreat in accord with the times,
To act and rest in harmony with principle—
Neither loving nor hating beauty and ugliness,
Neither rejoicing nor angering in rewards and punishments.

Names are self-bestowed,
Kinds are self-classified,
Affairs arise from nature—
None originate from oneself.
If one attempts to constrain them,
One only drives them further away.
If one attempts to embellish them,
One only robs them of their truth.

Heaven’s *qi* is the spirit,
Earth’s *qi* is the ether—
Reversed, they are profound and mysterious,
Each dwelling in its proper place,
Guarding them without loss,
Ascending to the *Taiyi* (Supreme Unity),
The essence of the *Taiyi* merging with Heaven.

The Way of Heaven is silent and silent again—
Without measure, without rule,
Great beyond extremity,
Deep beyond measure,
Ever transforming with humanity,
Wisdom cannot grasp it—
Its revolutions are endless,
Its transformations divine,
Its emptiness follows without leading.
When it governs and orders,
It is a heart of voidness, a spirit of weakness—
Yet clear and undimmed.
Thus all ministers gather like spokes to the hub,
None, whether wise or foolish, virtuous or base,
Fail to give their utmost—
The sovereign gains the means to govern his ministers,
The ministers gain the means to serve their sovereign,
And thus the Way of governing the state is made clear.

Laozi said:
*"Those who know and love to ask are sages,
Those who are courageous and love to ask are conquerors.*
*He who rides upon the wisdom of the multitude can accomplish anything,
He who uses the strength of the multitude can overcome anything.*
*He who uses the strength of the multitude need not rely on Wu Ge,
He who rides upon the power of the multitude need not rely on the world’s might.*
*Without authority, one cannot wield power,
Yet failing to follow the natural order of things,
Even sages cannot achieve renown."*

Therefore the sage, when acting,
Never fails to use their resources as they should—
One with a form occupies a place,
One with ability serves a task.
If their strength exceeds their role,
The burden of the one who raises them is not heavy.
If their ability exceeds their task,
The one who employs them finds no difficulty.

The sage combines and utilizes all—
Thus no person is cast aside, no talent neglected.

Laozi said:
*"So-called non-action is not to say that things are not drawn near when invited,
Nor pushed away when repelled,
Nor that they do not respond when pressed,
Nor that they are unmoved when stirred—
Nor that they are rigid and stagnant, yet do not flow,
Nor that they are coiled and grasped, yet do not disperse.*
*It means that private desires do not intrude upon public Dao,
That cravings do not cling to proper methods—*
*To act in accordance with principle,
To establish merit through one’s resources,
To follow the natural momentum of things,*
*Yet if one forces them, they cannot be contained—*
*To achieve success yet never claim it for oneself,*
*To set up merit yet never possess its name.*
*As water carries boats,
As ice aids the skater,
As mud supports the plow,
As mountains anchor the cart—*
*Summer’s floods, winter’s shallows,*
*High becomes mountain, low becomes pool,*
*None of this is my doing."*

chunks.original_text: 圣人不耻身之贱，恶道之不行也，不忧命之短，忧百姓之穷也，故常虚而无为，抱素见朴，不与物杂。 老子曰：古之立帝王者，非以奉养其欲也，圣人践位者，非以逸乐其身也，为天下之民，强陵弱，众暴寡，诈者欺愚，勇者侵怯，又为其怀智诈不以相教，积财不以相分，故立天子以齐一之。 一人之明，不能遍照海内，故立三公九卿以辅翼之。 为绝国殊俗，不得被泽，故立诸侯以教诲之。 是以天地四时无不应也，官无隐事，国无遗利，所以衣寒食饥，养老弱，息劳倦，无不以也。 神农形悴，尧瘦，舜黧黑，禹胼胝，伊尹负鼎而干汤，吕望鼓刀而入周，百里奚传卖，管仲束缚，孔子无黔突，墨子无暖席，非以贪禄慕位，将欲事起于天下之利，除万民之害也。 自天子至于庶人，四体不勤，思虑不困，于事求赡者，未之闻也。 老子曰：所谓天子者，有天道以立天下也。 立天下之道，执一以为保，反本无为，虚静无有，忽慌无无际，远无所止，视之无形，听之无声，是谓大道之经。 老子曰：夫道者，体员而法方，背阴而抱阳，左柔而右刚，履幽而戴明，变化无常，得一之原，以应无方，是谓神明。 天员而无端，故不得观，地方而无涯，故莫窥其门，天化遂无形状，地生长无计量。 夫物有胜，唯道无胜，所以无胜者，以其无常形势也，轮转无形，象日月之运行，若春秋之代谢，日月之昼夜，终而复始，明而复晦，制形而无形，故功可成，物物而不物，故胜而不屈。 庙战者帝，神化者王，庙战者法天道，神化者明四时，修正于境内，而远方怀德，制胜于未战，而诸侯宾服也。 古之得道者，静而法天地，动而顺日月，喜怒合四时。 号令比雷霆，音气不戾八风，诎伸不获五度。 因民之欲，乘民之力，为之去残除害，夫同利者相死，同情者相成，同行者相助，循己而动，天下为斗。 故善用兵者，用其自为用，不能用兵者，用其为己用，用其自为用，天下莫不可用，用其为己用，无一人之可用也。 卷第九 下德
chunks.translated_text:
The Sage does not shame himself for lowly station,
But hates the Dao’s failure to prevail.
He does not grieve his life’s short span,
But mourns the people’s dire want.
Thus ever empty, ever non-acting,
He embraces simplicity, reveals the unadorned,
And does not mingle with the myriad things.

Laozi says: The ancient founders of imperial rule
Did not establish it to indulge their desires.
The Sage who ascends the throne
Does not seek ease and pleasure for himself.
For the people of the world—
The strong oppress the weak,
The many tyrannize the few,
The cunning deceive the simple,
The bold assault the timid,
And those who hoard wisdom and guile
Do not share it with others,
Nor distribute their wealth.
Thus, the Son of Heaven is established
To unify and harmonize them.

One man’s wisdom cannot illuminate the land,
So the Three Ministers and Nine Officials are appointed
To assist and support him.
For distant lands and alien customs,
Unreached by his grace,
The feudal lords are set in place
To teach and guide them.
Thus, the heavens and four seasons respond in kind,
No official matter remains concealed,
No national benefit is overlooked—
All are employed to clothe the cold, feed the hungry,
Sustain the aged and infirm,
And rest the weary.

Shennong’s form was wasted,
Yao grew emaciated,
Shun’s skin darkened,
Yu’s hands were calloused.
Yi Yin carried a cauldron to serve Tang,
Zhuge Liang wielded a butcher’s knife before entering Zhou,
Bai Li Xi was sold into servitude,
Guan Zhong was bound in chains,
Confucius lacked a black ox for sacrifice,
Mozi had no warm seat—
Not for greed of office or love of rank,
But to awaken the world’s benefit,
To remove the harm from all people.

From the Son of Heaven to the commoner,
No one’s limbs grow idle,
No one’s thoughts remain unburdened,
Yet all find their needs met—
Such has never been heard of.

Laozi says: The Son of Heaven
Stands upon the Heavenly Dao to govern the world.
The Dao of governing the world
Holds to One as its safeguard,
Returns to the Root with non-action,
Is empty and tranquil, without possession,
Fleeting yet boundless,
Far-reaching yet without end,
Visible yet without form,
Audible yet without sound—
This is called the essence of the Great Dao.

Laozi says: The Dao
Embraces the round yet follows the square,
Backs the shady, cradles the sunny,
Left is soft, right is firm,
Treads the obscure while wearing the bright,
Transforms without constancy,
Draws from the One its origin,
To respond to the boundless—
This is called divine illumination.

Heaven is round yet has no end,
Thus it cannot be observed;
Earth is square yet has no boundary,
Thus no one can spy its gate.
Heaven’s transformations flow without form,
Earth’s growth extends without measure.

Things have their masters,
But the Dao has none—
For it has no fixed shape or force.
Like a wheel turning without form,
It mirrors the sun and moon’s revolutions,
Like the seasons’ succession,
Day and night’s cycle—
Ending to begin anew,
Brightness fading into darkness.
It shapes without form,
Thus its work is accomplished.
It nurtures all things without being possessed,
Thus it conquers without being overcome.

The warrior who fights in temples becomes an emperor,
The sage who transforms through spirit becomes a king.
The warrior who fights in temples follows the Heavenly Dao,
The sage who transforms through spirit aligns with the four seasons,
Correcting within his borders,
While distant lands embrace his virtue.
He conquers before battle is joined,
And the feudal lords come as guests in submission.

The ancients who attained the Dao
Were still yet modeled the heavens and earth,
Were active yet followed the sun and moon,
Their joy and anger harmonized with the four seasons.
Their commands resounded like thunder,
Their breath and qi did not clash with the eight winds,
Their bending and stretching did not violate the five phases.
They followed the people’s desires,
Rode the people’s strength,
Removed their残害 for them.
Those who share the same benefit will die for each other,
Those who share the same sentiment will succeed together,
Those who walk the same path will aid each other.
Move in accordance with their nature,
And the world becomes a single family.

Thus, the skilled warrior
Uses their own strength,
The unskilled warrior
Uses others’ strength for himself.
If he uses their own strength,
No one in the world cannot be used.
If he uses others’ strength for himself,
Not a single person can be employed.

chunks.original_text: 老子曰：治身，太上养神，其次养形，神清意平，百节皆宁，养生之本也，肥肌肤，充腹肠，供嗜欲，养生之末也。 治国，太上养化，其次正法，民交让争处卑，财利争受少，事力争就劳，日化上而迁善，不知其所以然，治之本也，利赏而劝善，畏刑而不敢为非，法令正于上，百姓服于下，治之末也，上世养本，而下世事末。 老子曰：欲治之主不世出，可与治之臣不万一，以不世出求不万一，此至治所以千岁不一也。 盖霸王之功不世立也，顺其善意，防其邪心，与民同出一道，则民可善，风俗可美。 所贵圣人者，非贵其随罪而作刑也，贵其知乱之所生也。 若开其锐端，而纵之放僻淫佚，而弃之以法，随之以刑，虽残贼天下不能禁其奸矣。 老子曰：身处江海之上，心在魏阙之下，即重生，重生即轻利矣。 犹不能自胜即从之，神无所害也，不能自胜而强不从，是谓重伤，重伤之人无寿类矣。 故曰：知和曰常，知常曰明，益生曰祥，心使气曰强，是谓玄同，用其光，复归其明。 老子曰：天下莫易于为善，莫难于为不善。 所谓为善者，静而无为，适情辞余，无所诱惑，循性保真，无变于己，故曰为善易也。 所谓为不善难者，篡弒矫诈，躁而多欲，非人之性也，故曰为不善难也。 今之以为大患者，由无常厌度量生也，故利害之地，祸福之际，不可不察。 圣人无欲也，无避也，事或欲之，适足以失之，事或避之，适足以就之，志有所欲，即忘其所为，是以圣人审动静之变，而适受与之度，理好憎之情，和喜怒之节。 夫动静得即患不侵也，受与适即罪不累也，理好憎即忧不近也，和喜怒即怨不犯也。 体道之人不苟得，不让祸，其有不弃，非其有不制，恒满而不溢，常虚而易赡。 故自当以道术度量，即食充虚，衣圉寒，足以温饱七尺之形，无道术度量，而以自要尊贵，即万乘之势不足以为快，天下之富不足以为乐，故圣人心平志易，精神内守，物不能惑。 老子曰：胜人者有力，自胜者强。 能强者，必用人力者也，能用人力者，必得人心者也，能得人心者，必自得者也，未有得己而失人者也，未有失己而得人者也。 故为治之本，务在安人，安人之本，在于足用，足用之本，在于不夺时，不夺时之本，在于省事，省事之本，在于节用，节用之本，在于去骄，去骄之本，在于虚无，故知生之情者，不务生之所无以为，知命之情者，不忧命之所无奈何。 目悦五色，口惟滋味，耳淫五声，七窍交争，以害一性，日引邪欲竭其天和，身且不能治，奈治天下何，所谓得天下者，非谓其履势位，称尊号，言其运天下心，得天下力也，有南面之名，无一人之誉，此失天下也。 故桀纣不为王，汤武不为放，故天下得道，在守四夷，天下失道，守在诸侯，诸侯得道，守在四境，诸侯失道，守在左右。 故曰无恃其不吾夺也，恃吾不可夺也，行可夺之道，而非篡弒之行，无益于持天下矣。 老子曰：善治国者，不变其故，不易其常。 夫怒者逆德也，兵者凶器也，争者人之所乱也，阴谋逆德，好用凶器，治人之乱，逆之至也。 非祸人不能成祸，不如挫其锐，解其纷，和其光，同其尘。 人之性情皆愿贤己而疾不及人，愿贤己则争心生，疾不及人则怨争生，怨争生则心乱而气逆，故古之圣王退争怨，争怨不生则心治而气顺，故曰不尚贤使民不争。

Laozi says: To govern oneself, the highest priority is to nourish the spirit (*shén*), the next to nourish the form (*xíng*). When the spirit is clear and the mind is tranquil, all hundred joints are at ease—this is the foundation of life-nourishment. Plump flesh and full belly, indulging in appetites—these are the superficial aspects of life-nourishment.

To govern a state, the highest priority is to nourish the natural order (*huà*), the next to uphold the laws. When people vie in yielding and humility, compete in receiving little of wealth and profit, and vie in embracing laborious tasks, day by day the natural order ascends and virtue improves—this, without knowing how, is the foundation of governance. When rewards and benefits encourage virtue, and fear of punishment prevents wrongdoing, laws and commands are established above while the people submit below—this is the superficial aspect of governance. In the ancient age, the foundation was cultivated, while in the later age, the superficial was attended to.

Laozi says: A ruler capable of governance does not appear in every age, nor does a minister capable of governance appear in every thousand. Seeking the latter with the former, this is why even the most refined governance is not found once in a thousand years.

The achievements of hegemons (*bàwáng*) are not established in every age. If one aligns with the people’s benevolent intentions and guards against their deceitful hearts, sharing the same Dao with them, then the people can be virtuous and customs refined.

What is precious about the Sage is not their imposition of punishments for crimes, but their understanding of where disorder arises. If one sharpens their malicious inclinations and lets them run wild in licentiousness and depravity, then abandons them to the law and follows them with punishment, even if one slaughters and plunders the world, they cannot suppress its deceit.

Laozi says: If one’s body rests above the rivers and seas, yet their heart lies beneath the palace gates, then they hold life dear, and cherishing life means they will not covet profit. If they cannot conquer themselves yet force others to submit, this is called harming oneself. Those who harm themselves will have no longevity.

Hence it is said: Knowing harmony is knowing constancy, knowing constancy is knowing wisdom, increasing life is auspiciousness, and directing the mind to move *qi* is strength—this is called the Mysterious Unity. Use its light, and return to its wisdom.

Laozi says: Nothing is easier than doing good, nothing is harder than not doing good. What is called doing good is to remain still and take no action, to follow one’s nature and abandon excess, to avoid all temptations and inducements, to follow one’s nature and preserve truth, to have no change within oneself. Hence, it is said that doing good is easy.

What is called not doing good is hard: usurpation and regicide, deceit and hypocrisy, impetuosity and excessive desires—these are not in accord with human nature. Hence, it is said that not doing good is hard.

Now, what is considered the greatest calamity arises from the absence of constancy, satiety, and moderation. Therefore, in matters of profit and harm, and at the juncture of misfortune and fortune, one must be vigilant.

The Sage has no desires, no evasions. If one pursues something, they may lose it; if one avoids something, they may gain it. If one’s resolve has something it desires, they will forget their purpose. This is why the Sage carefully discerns the changes between action and stillness, and adjusts their reception and giving accordingly. They harmonize the emotions of love and hate, and balance the rhythms of joy and anger.

If action and stillness are well-managed, calamity will not invade. If reception and giving are appropriate, guilt will not accumulate. If love and hate are properly balanced, sorrow will not approach. If joy and anger are harmonized, resentment will not arise.

Those who embody the Dao do not seek gains lightly nor shirk misfortune. If they do not abandon, it is not because they cannot restrain themselves, but because they are always full yet never overflowing, always empty yet easily replenished.

Hence, if one governs themselves with Daoist principles and moderation, then food will suffice to fill their emptiness, clothing to ward off cold, and this will be enough to ensure warmth and sustenance for their seven-foot form. Without Daoist principles and moderation, even if they demand the trappings of honor and nobility, the power of ten thousand chariots will not bring them satisfaction, nor will the wealth of the world bring them joy. Thus, the Sage remains tranquil in heart and easy in resolve, guarding their spirit within, and external things cannot disturb them.

Laozi says: Those who overcome others have strength, those who overcome themselves are strong. To be strong, one must necessarily employ others’ strength, and to employ others’ strength, one must necessarily win others’ hearts. To win others’ hearts, one must necessarily attain self-mastery. There has never been one who attained themselves yet lost others, nor one who lost themselves yet gained others.

Hence, the foundation of governance lies in calming the people, the foundation of calming the people lies in ensuring their sufficiency, the foundation of sufficiency lies in not encroaching upon their natural rhythms, the foundation of not encroaching lies in reducing their burdens, the foundation of reducing burdens lies in moderating their desires, the foundation of moderation lies in removing arrogance, and the foundation of removing arrogance lies in emptiness and non-being. Thus, those who know the nature of life do not labor for what they cannot attain, and those who know the nature of fate do not worry over what they cannot control.

The eyes delight in the five colors, the mouth craves flavors, the ears indulge in the five sounds—when the seven orifices vie in contention, they harm the singular nature (*yīxìng*). Day by day, they draw out licentious desires and exhaust their natural harmony (*tiān hé*). Even their own bodies cannot be governed, let alone the world. Those who claim to have gained the world are not those who occupy power and titles, assume noble names, or speak of ruling the world’s heart and strength. With the name of kingship yet no one’s praise, this is to have lost the world.

Hence, Jie and Zhou were not true kings, nor were Tang and Wu mere bandits. When the world gains the Dao, it rests in guarding the four frontier regions (*sìyí*), when the world loses the Dao, it rests in the hands of the feudal lords. When feudal lords gain the Dao, they rest in guarding their borders, when they lose the Dao, they rest in their own retainers. Hence it is said: Do not rely on others taking from you, but rely on your inability to be taken from. Practicing the Dao that can be seized, yet not engaging in usurpation and regicide, is of no benefit in maintaining the world.

Laozi says: The skilled ruler of a state does not alter their established ways nor change their constants. Anger is contrary to virtue, arms are instruments of violence, and contention is the source of disorder. Plotting in secret is contrary to virtue, delighting in violence is the use of instruments of violence, and managing disorder is the height of contradiction.

It is not possible to create calamity without harming others. It is better to blunt their sharpness, untangle their chaos, soften their brilliance, and equalize their dust. All people’s emotions and inclinations wish to be virtuous themselves yet resent others not reaching them. Wishing to be virtuous themselves gives rise to contentious hearts, resenting others not reaching them gives rise to grievances and contention. When grievances and contention arise, the heart is disordered and *qi* is rebellious. Hence, the ancient Sages retreated from contention and grievance. When contention and grievance do not arise, the heart is governed and *qi* is harmonious. Hence it is said: Do not exalt the virtuous, so that the people do not contend.

**Chapter Nine: Lower Virtue**

chunks.original_text: 老子曰：治物者，不以物以和，治和者，不以和以人，治人者，不以人以君，治君者，不以君以欲，治欲者，不以欲以性，治性者，不以性以德，治德者，不以德以道。 以道本人之性，无邪秽，久湛于物即忘其本，即合于若性。 衣食礼俗者，非人之性也，所受于外也，故人性欲平，嗜欲害之，唯有道者能遗物反己。 有以自鉴，则不失物之情，无以自鉴，则动而惑营。 夫纵欲失性，动未尝正，以治生则失身，以治国则乱人，故不闻道者无以反性。 古者圣人得诸己，故令行禁止，凡举事者，必先平意清神，神清意平，物乃可正。 听失于非誉，目淫于彩色，而欲得事正即难矣，是以贵虚。 故水激则波起，气乱则智昏，昏智不可以为正，波水不可以为平，故圣王执一，以理物之情性。 夫一者，至贵无适于天下，圣王托于无适，故为天下命。 老子曰：阴阳陶冶万物，皆乘一气而生。 上下离心，气乃上蒸，君臣不和，五谷不登，春肃秋荣，冬雷夏霜，皆贼气之所生也。 天地之间，一人之身也，六合之内，一人之形也，故明于性者，天地不能胁也，审于符者，怪物不能惑也。 圣人由近以知远，以万里为一同，气蒸乎天地，礼义廉耻不设，万民莫不相侵暴虐，由在乎混冥之中也。 廉耻陵，及至世之衰，害多而财寡，事力劳而养不足，民贫苦而忿争生，是以贵仁。 人鄙不齐，比周朋党，各推其与，怀机巧诈之心，是以贵义。 男女群居，杂而无别，是以贵礼。 性命之情，淫而相迫于不得已，则不和，是以贵乐。 故仁义礼乐者，所以救败也，非通治之道也。 诚能使神明定于天下，而心反其初，则民性善，民性善则天地阴阳从而包之，则财足而人赡，贪鄙忿争之心不得生焉。 仁义不害，而道德定而天下，而民不淫于彩色，故德衰然后饰仁义，和失然后调声，礼淫然后饰容。 故知道德，然后知仁义不足行也，知仁义，然后知礼乐不足修也。 老子曰：清静之治者，和顺以寂寞，质真而素朴，闲静而不躁，在内而合乎道，出外而同乎义，其言略而循理，其行悦而顺情，其心和而不伪，其事素而不饰，不谋所始，不议所终，安即即留，激即行，通体乎天地，同胃乎阴阳，一和乎四时，明朗乎日月，与道化者为人，机械诈伪莫载乎心。 是以天覆以德，地载以乐，四时不失序，风雨不为虐，日月清静而扬光，五星不失其行，此清静之所明也。 老子曰：治世之职易守也，其事易为也，其礼易行也，其责易赏也。 是以人不兼官，官不兼士，士农工商，乡别州异，故农与农言藏，士与士言行，工与工言巧，商与商言数。 是以士无遗行，工无苦事，农无废功，商无折货，各安其性。 异形殊类，易事而不悖，失处而贱，得势而贵。 夫先知远见之人，才之盛也，而治世不以责于人，博闻强志，口辩辞给，人知之溢也，而明主不以求于下，敖世贱物，不从流俗，士之伉行也，而治世不以为化民。 故高不可及者，不以为人量，行不可逮者，不可为国俗，故人才不可专用，而度量道术可世传也。 故国治可与愚守也，而军旅可以法同也，不待古之英俊，而人自足者，因其所有而并用之。 末世之法，高为量而罪不及也，重为任而罚不胜也，危为其难而诛不敢也，民困于三责，即饰智而诈上，犯邪而行危，虽峻法严刑，不能禁其奸。
chunks.translated_text:
The Master Laozi says: Those who govern things do not rely on things to achieve harmony; those who govern harmony do not rely on harmony to govern people; those who govern people do not rely on people to govern the ruler; those who govern the ruler do not rely on the ruler to govern desires; those who govern desires do not rely on desires to govern nature; those who govern nature do not rely on nature to govern virtue; those who govern virtue do not rely on virtue to govern the Dao/Way.

To govern with the Dao/Way as the foundation of people’s nature, there is no perversion or impurity. If one lingers long among things, they forget their foundation, and thus align with the nature of things.

Clothing, food, rites, and customs are not the nature of people; they are imposed from without. Thus, when people’s nature is balanced, excessive desires harm them. Only those who follow the Dao/Way can abandon things and return to their true selves.

If one can self-reflect, they will not lose the essence of things; if they cannot, their actions will only breed confusion and deceit.

To indulge desires is to lose one’s nature; when actions are unrestrained, they are never correct. To govern life with such unrestrained actions is to lose one’s body; to govern the state is to incite chaos among the people. Hence, those who do not hear the Dao/Way cannot return to their true nature.

The ancient Sages understood all from within themselves, so their commands were carried out and forbidden acts ceased. When undertaking any matter, one must first calm their intentions and clarify their mind. When the mind is clear and intentions are calm, then the affairs of things can be set right.

To hear only praise or blame, to gaze lustfully upon colors and hues, makes it difficult to achieve order in governance. Hence, the value of emptiness.

Thus, water stirred will raise waves, and rebellious *qi* will cloud the mind. A clouded mind cannot govern correctly, and waves cannot settle into stillness. Therefore, the ancient Sages held to the One, to regulate the emotions and inclinations of things.

The One is the most precious, without limit in the world. The ancient Sages entrusted themselves to the limitless, thus they could command all under Heaven.

The Master Laozi says: Yin and Yang refine all things, all riding upon the One *qi* to emerge. When the ruler and subjects are divided in heart, *qi* ascends and stagnates. When the ruler and ministers are not in harmony, the five grains do not flourish. When spring is stern and autumn withers, when winter thunders and summer frosts, these are all born of the disruption of *qi*.

Between Heaven and Earth, there is but one body; within the six directions, there is but one form. Thus, those who understand nature cannot be coerced by Heaven and Earth, and those who discern omens cannot be deceived by strange creatures.

The Sages know the near to understand the far, considering ten thousand *li* as one measure. When *qi* rises to Heaven and Earth, rites, justice, and propriety are not established, and the people all violate one another, committing cruelty and violence. This arises from their being lost in the murky chaos.

When justice and shame are neglected, and the age declines, harm increases while wealth diminishes. Labor is excessive while sustenance is insufficient. The people grow poor and wretched, and resentment and contention arise. Hence, the value of *ren*.

When people are coarse and unequal, forming cliques and factions, each promoting their own, harboring cunning and deceitful hearts, hence the value of *yi*.

When men and women dwell together without distinction, hence the value of rites.

When the emotions of life are unrestrained and press upon one another in desperation, they become discordant. Hence, the value of music.

Thus, *ren*, *yi*, rites, and music are means to remedy failures, not universal paths to governance.

If one can truly settle the mind and return to its original state, then the people’s nature is good. When the people’s nature is good, Heaven and Earth’s Yin and Yang will follow and encompass them, ensuring wealth and nourishment for all. The hearts of greed, coarseness, resentment, and contention will not arise.

*Ren* and *yi* do not harm, while virtue and the Dao/Way are established, and the world is governed. The people will not indulge in colors and hues. Thus, when virtue decays, *ren* and *yi* are adorned; when harmony is lost, music is adjusted; when rites are violated, appearance is refined.

Hence, knowing the Dao/Way and virtue, one then knows that *ren* and *yi* are insufficient for action; knowing *ren* and *yi*, one then knows that rites and music are insufficient for cultivation.

The Master Laozi says: Governance through purity and stillness is to be in harmony and order, yet tranquil and unassuming. It is simple and true, yet undyed and unadorned. It is calm and quiet, yet not restless. Within, it aligns with the Dao/Way; without, it conforms with *yi*. Its words are concise yet follow principle; its actions are pleasing yet accord with human nature. Its heart is harmonious yet unfeigned; its affairs are plain yet undecorated. It does not contrive beginnings nor debate endings. It remains settled when at ease, and moves when stirred. Its body resonates with Heaven and Earth, its essence with Yin and Yang. It harmonizes with the four seasons, its radiance with the sun and moon. It acts in accordance with the Dao/Way’s transformations, and cunning, mechanical deceit and pretense have no place in its heart.

Thus, Heaven covers with virtue, Earth bears with music. The four seasons do not lose their order, winds and rains do not act capriciously. The sun and moon are pure and still, shining forth their light. The five stars do not lose their courses—this is the clarity of purity and stillness.

The Master Laozi says: In a well-governed age, the duties of governance are easily upheld, its affairs are easily managed, its rites are easily followed, its rewards are easily bestowed.

Thus, one person does not hold multiple offices, and an official does not hold the rank of a scholar. Scholars, farmers, artisans, and merchants dwell in separate districts and states, so farmers speak of farming to farmers, scholars speak of conduct to scholars, artisans speak of skill to artisans, and merchants speak of numbers to merchants.

Thus, scholars have no neglected conduct, artisans no laborious tasks, farmers no wasted effort, and merchants no losses in trade—each finds contentment in their nature.

Though forms and types differ, their affairs are simple yet not contradictory. When placed in lowly positions, they are despised; when in power, they are honored.

Those who possess foresight and far-reaching vision are the most talented, yet in a well-governed age, they are not burdened with responsibilities. Those who are widely learned and resolute in will, quick-tongued and eloquent, are the most knowledgeable, yet enlightened rulers do not seek such qualities from their subjects. Those who scorn the world and hold others in contempt, who do not conform to common customs, are the most virtuous in conduct, yet in a well-governed age, they are not used to transform the people.

Hence, those whose height is unattainable are not set as measures for others; those whose conduct cannot be emulated are not made the customs of the state. Thus, individual talents cannot be monopolized, while measures, virtue, and Dao/Way can be passed down through the ages.

Therefore, when a state is well-governed, even the foolish can uphold it; and its military can be organized by law alone. It does not depend on ancient heroes, but the people are naturally sufficient—using what they possess and combining their strengths.

The laws of the declining age set high standards yet punishments do not reach those who fail; impose heavy burdens yet penalties cannot overcome the offense; establish perilous dangers yet executions are not dared. The people are burdened by these three demands, and thus feign cleverness to deceive their superiors, act wickedly, and court danger. Even with harsh laws and severe punishments, they cannot be deterred from their deceit.

Wishing to be virtuous themselves gives rise to contentious hearts, resenting others not reaching them gives rise to grievances and contention. When grievances and contention arise, the heart is disordered and *qi* is rebellious. Hence, the ancient Sages retreated from contention and grievance. When contention and grievance do not arise, the heart is governed and *qi* is harmonious. Hence it is said: Do not exalt the virtuous, so that the people do not contend.

chunks.original_text: 兽穷即触，鸟穷即啄，人穷即诈，此之谓也。 老子曰：雷霆之声可以钟鼓象也，风雨之变可以音律知也，大可睹者，可得而量也，明可见者，可得而蔽也，声可闻者，可得而调也，色可察者，可得而别也。 夫至大，天地不能函也，至微，神明不能见也，及至建律历，别五色，异清浊，味甘苦，即朴散而为器矣。 立仁义，修礼乐，即德迁而为伪矣。 民饰智以惊愚，设诈以攻上，天下有能持之，而未能有治之者也。 夫智能弥多，而德滋衰，是以至人淳朴而不散。 夫至人之治，虚无寂寞，不见可欲，心与神处，形与性调，静而体德，动而理通，循自然之道，缘不得已矣。 漠然无为而天下和，淡然无欲而民自朴，不忿争而财足，求者不得，受者不让，德反归焉，而莫之惠。 不言之辩，不道之道，若或通焉，谓之天府。 取焉而不损，酌焉而不竭，莫知其所求由，谓之摇光，摇光者，资粮万物者也。 老子曰：天爱其精，地爱其平，人爱其情，天之精，日月星辰、雷霆风雨也，地之平，水火金木土也，人之情，思虑聪明喜怒也，故闭其四关，止五道，即与道沦。 神明藏于无形，精气反于真，目明而不以视，耳聪而不以听，口当而不以言，心条通而不以思虑，委而不为，知而不矜，直性命之情，而知故不得害。 精存于目即其视明，在于耳即其听聪，留于口即其言当，集于心即其虑通，故闭四关即终身无患，四支九窍，莫死莫生，是谓真人。 地之生财，大本不过五行，圣人节五行，即治不荒。 老子曰：衡之于左右，无私轻重，故可以为平，绳之于内外，无私曲直，故可以为正，人主之于法，无私好憎，故可以为令，德无所立，怨无所藏，是任道而合人心者也。 故为治者，知不与焉，水戾破舟，木击折轴，不怨木石而罪巧拙者，智不载也，故道有智则乱，德有心则险，心有眼则眩。 夫权衡规矩，一定而不易，常一而不邪，方行而不留，一日形之，万世传之，无为之为也。 人之言曰：国有亡主，世亡亡道，人有穷而理无不通，故无为者，道之宗也。 得道之宗，并应无穷，故不因道理之数，而专己之能，其穷中远。 夫人君者不出户以知天下者，因物以识物，因人以知人。 故积力之所举，即无不胜也，众智之为，即无不成也。 千人之众无绝粮，万人之群无废功，工无异伎，士无兼官，各守其职，不得相予，人得所宜，物得所安，是以器械不恶，职事不慢也。 夫责少易偿也，职寡易守也，任轻易劝也，上操约少之分，下效易为之功，是以居日久而不相厌也。 老子曰：帝者体太一，王者法阴阳，霸者则四时，君者用六律。 体太一者，明于天地之情，通于道德之伦，聪明照于日月，精神通于万物，动静调于阴阳，嗔怒和于四时，覆露皆道，溥洽而无私，蜎飞蠕动，莫不依德而生，德流方外，名声传乎后世。 法阴阳者，承天地之和，德与天地参，光明与日月并照，精神与鬼神齐灵，圆履方，枹表寝绳，内能理身，外得人心，发施号令，天下从风，则四时者，春生夏长，秋收冬藏，取与有节，出入有量，喜怒刚柔，不离其理，柔而不脆，刚而不折，宽而不肆，肃而不悖，优游委顺，以养群类，其德含愚而容不肖，无所私爱也。

The beasts when driven to extremity will gore, the birds when driven to extremity will peck, and humankind when driven to extremity will deceive—this is what is meant.

Laozi said:
The thunderous voice of *lei-ting* can be imitated by bells and drums,
the shifts of wind and rain can be known through music’s tones.
What is vast enough to be seen can be measured,
what is bright enough to be seen can be obscured,
what can be heard can be tuned,
what can be observed can be distinguished.
Yet what is supremely vast, even heaven and earth cannot contain it,
and what is supremely subtle, even the divine cannot perceive it.
When laws are established, the five colors distinguished,
pure and turbid separated, flavors of sweet and bitter discerned—
then the uncarved block is scattered into tools.

When *ren* and *yi* are instituted, and rites and music refined,
virtue/power shifts into artifice.
The people adorn their cunning to astonish the simple,
employ deceit to assault their superiors—
though some may uphold such ways, none can govern by them.

The more clever one becomes, the more virtue/power decays.
Thus, the sage remains pure and undivided.

The sage’s governance is empty, silent, and still—
no desires are seen, the heart and spirit dwell in harmony,
the form aligns with nature, and movement flows with principle.
Following the Dao/Way naturally, acting only when unavoidable—
without action, the world finds peace;
without desire, the people return to simplicity;
without resentment, resources suffice.
Those who seek do not obtain, those who receive do not refuse—
virtue/power returns of its own accord, yet none bestows it.

Speech without words, the Dao/Way without teaching—
if one attains this, it is called the Heavenly Treasury.
Take from it without depletion, draw from it without exhaustion—
none know its source, yet it is called *yao-guang*,
the *yao-guang* being the sustenance of all things.

Laozi said:
Heaven cherishes its essence, earth cherishes its level,
humankind cherishes its emotions—
the essence of heaven: sun, moon, stars, thunder, wind, and rain;
the level of earth: water, fire, metal, wood, and soil;
the emotions of humankind: thought, perception, cleverness, joy, and anger.
Thus, close the four gates, halt the five paths,
and you will merge with the Dao/Way.
The divine hides in formlessness, the essence returns to truth—
eyes bright yet do not see, ears keen yet do not listen,
the mouth speaks rightly yet does not speak,
the heart’s clarity flows yet does not deliberate.
Surrender without action, know without arrogance,
align with nature’s essence, and harm cannot touch you.
Essence in the eyes sharpens vision,
in the ears sharpens hearing,
in the mouth ensures truthfulness,
in the heart ensures wisdom—
thus, closing the four gates brings lifelong peace.
The four limbs and nine orifices know neither death nor life—
this is called the True Person.

Earth’s production of wealth relies on no more than the Five Phases;
the sage regulates the Five Phases, and governance does not falter.

Laozi said:
The balance’s equilibrium between left and right,
without partiality in lightness or weight, thus it can be level.
The plumb line’s alignment within and without,
without partiality in crookedness or straightness, thus it can be true.
The ruler’s adherence to law,
without partiality in favor or dislike, thus it can be command.
When virtue/power has no foundation, resentment has no place—
this is to entrust oneself to the Dao/Way and harmonize with human hearts.

Thus, those who govern should not interfere—
water overturns the boat, wood strikes the axle,
yet blame is not placed on wood or stone but on clumsy skill.
Wisdom cannot bear this.
Hence, when the Dao/Way has wisdom, chaos ensues;
when virtue/power has intent, danger arises;
when the mind has eyes, dizziness follows.

The scales, compass, and square—
fixed and unchanging, ever consistent and unerring,
moving straight without hesitation—
once shaped, they endure for ten thousand generations,
yet their essence is *wuwei*.

People say:
A state has a doomed ruler, an age doomed by its Dao/Way,
but a person may reach exhaustion while principle remains unbroken.
Thus, *wuwei* is the essence of the Dao/Way.
Attaining the Dao/Way’s essence,
its responses are boundless—
yet without relying on the numbers of principle,
but solely on one’s own capacity,
one’s limits are distant.

The sovereign need not leave the palace to know the world—
observe things to know things, observe people to know people.
Thus, the strength gathered can overcome all,
the collective wisdom can achieve all.
A thousand-strong force lacks no provisions,
a ten-thousand-strong host lacks no purpose—
artisans have no conflicting skills,
scholars hold no dual offices,
each guards their duty, none encroaches,
people find their place, things find their rest—
thus, tools are not despised, duties are not neglected.

When demands are few, they are easily met;
when duties are few, they are easily upheld;
when burdens are light, effort is encouraged.
The ruler holds a modest share, the people achieve effortless success—
thus, even after long years, they do not grow weary.

Laozi said:
The *Di* embodies the *Taiyi*,
the *Wang* follows *yin-yang*,
the *Ba* conforms to the four seasons,
the *Jun* employs the six *lü*.
To embody the *Taiyi* is to understand heaven and earth’s nature,
to harmonize with the moral order of virtue/power and Dao/Way,
to shine with the clarity of sun and moon,
to resonate with the spirit of all things,
to move and rest in accord with *yin-yang*,
to temper anger with the four seasons—
all things, great and small, depend on virtue/power for life.
Virtue/power extends beyond the realm, its fame endures through ages.

To follow *yin-yang* is to inherit heaven and earth’s harmony,
to share virtue/power with heaven and earth,
to shine with the brilliance of sun and moon,
to match the spirits with the divine—
to walk squarely, stand upright,
to align the drum and plumb line within,
to regulate the body internally, win hearts externally,
to issue commands—all under heaven follows the wind.
The four seasons: spring grows, summer lengthens,
autumn harvests, winter stores—
giving and taking are measured, entry and exit are quantified,
joy and anger, firmness and gentleness, never stray from principle.
Gentle yet not brittle, firm yet not rigid,
broad yet not licentious, solemn yet not rebellious—
easy and yielding, nurturing all beings,
its virtue encompasses the foolish and contains the unworthy,
yet it loves none in particular.

chunks.original_text: 用六律者，生之与杀也，赏之与罚也，与之以夺也，非此无道也，伐乱禁暴，兴贤废不肖，匡邪以为正，怀险以为平，矫枉以为直，明于施令，开塞之道，乘时因势，以服役人心者也。 帝者体阴阳即寝，王者法四时即削，霸者用六律即辱，君者失准绳即废，故小而行大即穷塞而不亲，大而行小即狭隘而不容。 老子曰：地广民众，不足以为强，甲坚兵利，不可以恃胜，城高池深，不足以为固，严刑峻罚，不足以为威。 为存政者，虽小必存焉，为亡政者，虽大必亡焉。 故善守者无与御，善战者无与斗，乘时势，因民欲，而天下服。 故善为政者，积其德，善用兵者，畜其怒，德积而民可用也，怒畜而威可立也。 故文之所加者，深则权之所服者大，德之所施者博，则威之所制者广，广即我强而适弱。 善用兵者，先弱敌而后战，故费不半而功十倍。 故千乘之国行文德者王，万乘之国好用兵者亡，王兵先胜而后战，败兵先战而后求胜，此不明于道也。 卷第十 上仁

To employ the Six Pitches is to give life and to take it,
to bestow rewards and to mete out punishments,
to grant and to seize—
without these, there is no Dao.

To strike down chaos and curb violence,
to elevate the worthy and discard the unworthy,
to correct the crooked and restore the straight,
to embrace the perilous and make it secure,
to bend the twisted and make it upright—
this is the Way of issuing commands,
the means to open blockages.

To harness the times and leverage circumstances,
to serve and guide the hearts of the people—
this is how one governs.

The **Son of Heaven** attunes to **yin-yang** and rests,
the **King** follows the Four Seasons and is diminished,
the **Conqueror** employs the Six Pitches and is shamed,
the **Lord** loses his plumb line and is deposed.

Thus, when small in action yet grand in effect, one is confined and distant;
when grand in action yet small in effect, one is narrow and unyielding.

**Laozi** said:
*"Though the land be vast and the people many, this cannot make one strong;
though armor be hard and weapons sharp, this cannot ensure victory;
though walls be high and moats deep, this cannot make one secure;
though punishments be severe and laws harsh, this cannot establish true威."*

For those who preserve their governance, even smallness must endure;
for those who lose their governance, even greatness must perish.

Thus, the skilled defender needs no rival to resist,
the skilled warrior needs no rival to fight,
harnessing the times and circumstances,
aligning with the people’s desires—
and all under heaven submits.

Therefore, the skilled ruler accumulates **virtue**,
the skilled warrior stores his **anger**,
for **virtue** accumulated makes the people obedient,
and **anger** stored establishes **威**.

Where **文** is applied deeply,
the **权** that submits is vast;
where **德** is bestowed broadly,
the **威** that commands is wide—
wide and yet adaptable, strong and yet yielding.

The skilled warrior weakens his enemy first, then engages in battle—
thus his costs are halved while his gains are tenfold.

Therefore, a realm of a thousand chariots ruled by **文德** becomes a **Kingdom**,
a realm of ten thousand chariots fond of war perishes—
the **King’s** forces first secure victory, then fight,
the **defeated’s** forces first fight, then seek victory—
this is ignorance of the Dao.

chunks.original_text: 老子曰：君子之道，静以修身，俭以养生。 静即下不扰，下不扰即民不怨，下扰即政乱，民怨即德薄，政乱贤者不为谋，德薄勇者不为斗。 乱主则不然，一日有天下之富，处一主之势，竭百姓之力，以奉耳目之欲，志专于宫室台榭，沟池苑囿，猛兽珍怪，贫民饥饿，虎狼厌刍豢，百姓冻寒，宫室衣绮绣，故人主畜兹旡用之物，而天下不安其性命矣。 老子曰：非惔漠无以明德，非宁静无以致远，非宽大无以并覆，非正平无以制断，以天下之目视，以天下之耳听，以天下之心虑，以天下之力争，故号令能下究，而臣情得上闻，百官条通，群臣辐凑。 喜不以赏赐，怒不以罪诛，法令察而不苛，耳目通而不暗，善否之情，日陈于前而不逆，故贤者尽其智，不肖者竭其力，近者安其性，远者怀其德，得用人之道。 夫乘舆马者，不劳而致千里，乘舟楫者不游而济江海，使言之而是，虽商夫刍荛，犹不可弃也，言之而非，虽在人君卿相，犹不可用也，是非之处，不可以贵贱尊卑论也。 其计可用，不羞其位，其言可行，不贵其辩，暗主则不然，群臣尽诚效忠者，希不用其身也，而亲习邪枉，贤者不能见也，疏远卑贱，竭力尽忠者不能闻也。 有言者穷之以辞，有谏者诛之以罪，如此而欲安海内、存万方，其离聪明亦以远矣。 老子曰：能尊生，虽富贵不以养伤身，虽贫贱不以利累形。 今受先祖之遗爵，必重生之所由来之矣，而轻失之，岂不惑哉。 贵以身治天下，可以寄天下，爱以身治天下，所以托天下矣。 文子问治国之本。 老子曰：本在于治身，未尝闻身治而国乱，身乱而国治也。 故曰：修之身，其德乃真。 道之所以至妙者，父不能以教子，子亦不能受之于父，故道可道，非常道也，名可名，非常名也。 文子问曰：何行而民亲其上？ 老子曰：使之以时而敬慎之，如临深渊，如履薄冰，天地之间，善即吾畜也，不善即吾雠也，昔者夏商之臣，反雠桀纣，而臣汤武，宿沙之民，自攻其君，归神农氏，故曰：「人之所畏，不可不畏也。 」 老子曰：治大者，道不可以小，地广者，制不可以狭，位高者，事不可以烦，民众者，教不可以苛。 事烦难治，法苛难行，求多难赡，寸而度之，至丈必差，铢而解之，至石必过，石称丈量，径而寡失，大较易为智，曲辩难为慧。 故无益于治，有益于乱者，圣人不为也，无益于用者，有益于费者，智者不行也。 故功不厌约，事不厌省，求不厌寡，功约易成，事省易治，求寡易赡，任于众人则易。 故小辩害义，小义破道，道小必不通，通必简。 河以逶迤故能远，山以陵迟故能高，道以优游故能化。 夫通于一伎，审于一事，察于一能，可以曲说，不可以广应也。 夫调音者，小弦急，大弦缓，立事者，贱者劳，贵者佚。 道之言曰：芒芒昧昧，因天之威，与天同气。 同气者帝，同义者王，同功者霸，无一焉者亡。 故不言而信，不施而仁，不怒而威，是以天心动化者也。 施而仁，言而信，怒而威，是以精诚为之者也，施而不仁，言而不信，怒而不威，是以外貌为之者也。 故有道以理之，法虽少，足以治，无道以理之，法虽众，足以乱。 老子曰：鲸鱼失水，则制于蝼蚁，人君舍其所守，而与臣争事，则制于有司，以无为持位，守职者以听从取容，臣下藏智而不用，反以事专其上。
chunks.translated_text:
「The Master Laozi says: The **Dao/Way** of the **君子** is to remain **静** in order to cultivate the self, and to practice **俭** to nourish life. **静** means the lower does not disturb; the lower not disturbed means the people do not grumble. When the lower disturbs, governance is chaotic; when the people grumble, **virtue/power** is thin. In chaos, the wise do not plot for him; with thin **virtue/power**, the brave do not fight for him.

But the disordered ruler is otherwise: in one day he may possess the wealth of the world, wield the power of a sovereign, exhaust the people’s strength, and indulge the desires of his ears and eyes. His mind is fixed on palaces, pavilions, moats, and gardens filled with rare beasts and strange treasures. The common folk suffer hunger and cold, while his halls are adorned with embroidered silks. Thus, though the ruler hoards these useless things, the world does not find peace in his reign.

The Master Laozi says: Without **惔漠** (indifference), one cannot clarify **德** (**virtue/power**). Without **宁静** (tranquility), one cannot attain the distant. Without **宽大** (magnanimity), one cannot unite and cover all. Without **正平** (justice and fairness), one cannot make judgments. To see with the eyes of the world, to hear with the ears of the world, to deliberate with the hearts of the world, and to contend with the strength of the world—thus his commands can reach the depths, and the emotions of his subjects can ascend to his ears. All officials follow their duties in order, and ministers gather like spokes to the hub.

He does not reward for joy, nor punish for anger. His laws and decrees are clear yet not harsh; his senses are open yet not obscured. The merits and faults of his subjects are laid before him daily, yet he does not resist them. Thus the wise exhaust their intelligence, the unworthy exert their strength, those near secure their livelihood, and those far away cherish his **德** (**virtue/power**). This is the **Dao/Way** of employing people.

He who rides in the royal carriage does not labor yet reaches a thousand *li*. He who sails in a boat does not swim yet crosses rivers and seas. If a man’s words are true, even though he be a common laborer or herdsman, he must not be discarded. If a man’s words are false, even though he be a king or prime minister, he must not be used. The judgment of truth and falsehood cannot be decided by rank or status.

The wise do not shame those whose counsel is useful, nor do they prize those whose words are merely eloquent. The foolish ruler is otherwise: those ministers who sincerely offer their loyalty, he seldom employs, while he favors those who are familiar with deceit and perversion. The wise he cannot see, nor does he hear the words of those who are distant and lowly, though they exert their strength in loyalty.

He who speaks is challenged with words, he who remonstrates is punished with crimes. Yet such a ruler wishes to bring peace to the seas within his borders and preserve all under heaven—how far he is from wisdom!

The Master Laozi says: He who can **尊生** (honor life) will not harm his body with wealth and honor, nor burden his form with poverty and meanness. Now, having inherited the noble rank of our ancestors, one must surely cherish the source of life’s origin, yet neglects its loss—is this not perplexing?

To govern the world with **身** (the self), one may entrust it to the world. To love the world with **身** (the self), one may thereby be entrusted with the world.

**Wénzǐ** asked: What is the foundation of ruling a state?

The Master Laozi replied: The foundation lies in governing oneself. Never have I heard of one who governs himself yet brings disorder to his state, nor of one who brings disorder to himself yet governs his state well.

Thus it is said: Cultivate it in the self, and its **德** (**virtue/power**) will be true.

The **Dao/Way** is so supremely wondrous that a father cannot teach it to his son, nor can a son receive it from his father. Hence, the **Dao/Way** that can be spoken is not the constant **Dao/Way**; the name that can be named is not the constant name.

**Wénzǐ** asked: How does one act so that the people love their ruler?

The Master Laozi replied: One must govern them with due **时** (timing) and treat them with **敬慎** (reverence and caution), as though standing at the edge of a deep abyss or walking on thin ice. Between heaven and earth, the good I nurture, the wicked I destroy. In ancient times, the ministers of **夏** and **商**, turning against the tyrants **桀** and **纣**, served **Tāng** and **Wǔ**. The people of **Hòushā** (Hostile Sands), attacking their own ruler, returned to the **Shénnóng** (Divine Farmer). Hence it is said: *“What the people fear, one must not fail to fear.”*

The Master Laozi says: In governing the great, the **Dao/Way** cannot be small. In lands vast, the rule cannot be narrow. In high stations, affairs cannot be burdensome. In states with many people, instruction cannot be harsh.

Burdensome affairs are hard to govern, harsh laws are hard to enforce, excessive demands are hard to satisfy. Measure by the inch, and even a *zhàng* (ten feet) will be wrong; weigh by the *zhū* (small weight), and even a *dàn* (one hundred *catty*) will be off. Yet if one uses a *zhàng* to measure a *zhàng* and a *dàn* to weigh a *dàn*, few errors will occur. Great comparisons are easily made with wisdom, while intricate arguments are hard to resolve with true insight.

Thus, what harms governance yet aids disorder, the sage does not practice; what does not aid utility yet increases expenditure, the wise do not follow.

Hence, efforts are not weary of being frugal, affairs are not weary of being simplified, demands are not weary of being few. Frugal efforts are easy to accomplish, simplified affairs are easy to govern, few demands are easy to satisfy, and when entrusted to the common people, it is easy.

Thus, petty eloquence harms **义** (righteousness), petty righteousness undermines the **Dao/Way**. If the **Dao/Way** is petty, it will not prevail; if it prevails, it must be simple.

The river flows far because it winds gently, the mountain stands high because it rises gradually. The **Dao/Way** transforms because it moves effortlessly.

He who is skilled in one art, precise in one matter, or discerning in one talent may be able to argue cleverly, but cannot apply broadly.

He who tunes music knows that small strings must be tight and large ones slack. He who establishes affairs knows that the lowly must labor while the noble must rest.

The words of the **Dao/Way** say: *“Vague and obscure, aligning with heaven’s **威** (awe), harmonizing with heaven’s **气** (qi).”* One who harmonizes with **气** (qi) becomes **帝** (Emperor), one who harmonizes with **义** (righteousness) becomes **王** (King), one who harmonizes with **功** (achievement) becomes **霸** (Hegemon). One who lacks all three perishes.

Thus, he does not speak yet is believed, does not act yet is kind, does not rage yet commands **威** (awe). Hence, his transformations move with the **天心** (heavenly intent).

If he acts yet is not kind, if he speaks yet is not trusted, if he rages yet does not command **威** (awe), then he is merely performing the outward appearance.

Thus, with the **Dao/Way** to guide, even few laws are sufficient for governance. Without the **Dao/Way**, even many laws are sufficient for disorder.

The Master Laozi says: A whale removed from water is dominated by ants. A ruler who abandons his proper course and contends with his ministers is dominated by his officials. To hold one’s station with **无为** (**wuwei**—non-action), those who guard their duties take pleasure in compliance. The ministers conceal their wisdom and do not use it, instead devoting themselves to the ruler’s affairs.»
